articles.title: LIGO is 10 years old: black-hole breakthroughs will ‘only get better’
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02941-9A decade after the pair of observatories first detected gravitational waves, researchers are drawing up ambitious plans for its successors.
articles.content:
The Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) facility, in Hanford, Washington.Credit: IMAGO/Xinhua via Alamy

Ten years after the historic discovery of gravitational waves, and having spotted hundreds more of these space-time swells since then, physicists say they are only just getting started.

On 14 September 2015, the twin facilities of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO), in Hanford, Washington, and Livingston, Louisiana, sensed the passing of ripples in space-time that had originated more than a billion years ago in the cataclysmic merger of two black holes, many galaxies away.

Clearest gravitational wave detection yet confirms Hawking’s black hole theory

That milestone took more than four decades of breakthroughs and heroic improvements in experimental techniques. But seeing such black-hole ‘binaries’ has now become routine. The LIGO detectors — alongside their sister observatories Virgo, near Pisa, Italy, and KAGRA, under Mount Ikenoyama, Japan — have roughly doubled their sensitivity over the past ten years, enabling them to monitor a region of the Universe that is twice as wide and contains about eight times as many galaxies. “We see binary black holes every three days on average now, which is pretty amazing to me,” says David Reitze, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena and longtime director of the LIGO observatories. “It’s only going to get better.”

Over the next decade, teams in both the United States and Europe are hoping to build bigger observatories that can spot gravitational waves from anywhere across the observable Universe. Nature takes a look at scientists’ plans for the next generation of gravitational-wave detectors.

Cosmic Explorer

US-based gravitational-wave researchers want to build the Cosmic Explorer (CE), an interferometer similar to LIGO, but with L-shaped arms that are ten times longer, stretching 40 kilometres. If it is built and works as planned, the CE should collect 100,000 black-hole mergers each year, essentially spotting them wherever they happen in the observable Universe. These will include events that happened more than ten billion years ago, when galaxies were at their busiest creating and destroying stars and making and merging black holes, says Reitze. “You really do want to be able to probe farther back.”

Each year, the CE would also pick up more than one million mergers of lighter objects called neutron stars — a rate of or one every several seconds, says Stefan Ballmer, a physicist at Syracuse University in New York.

But building it will not be cheap. With its arms stretching far beyond the horizon, the CE will run into the curvature of the Earth. If the endpoints are built at the ground level, the middle points will have to reach some 30 metres below the surface. Physicists have been scouting the United States for remote locations that are naturally bowl-shaped, which could reduce the need for digging. “We are winnowing the candidate sites down to a shortlist,” says Ballmer.

LIGO upgrades

Meanwhile, a planned set of upgrades called LIGO A# (A-sharp) could more than double the sensitivity of the existing observatory in the early 2030s, and help to test the cutting-edge technology that will eventually go into the CE. Improvements will include raising the power of the lasers that run down the interferometer arms. The LIGO team also plans to install heavier, more stable and more perfectly reflective suspended mirrors at the ends of those arms. (Interferometers detect gravitational waves by measuring tiny changes in the amount of time it takes for laser light to bounce between the mirrors.)

However, both the continued funding for maintaining LIGO and that for any upgrades — let alone new US-based facilities — could be at risk if President Donald Trump achieves his target of severely downsizing the US National Science Foundation, the agency that has funded most of LIGO’s construction and operation. Congress has hinted that it might prefer less-drastic cuts, however, and researchers remain hopeful. “I think we just have to wait and see,” Reitze says.

articles.personality_title: LIGO marks 10 years of black hole discoveries with plans for even better detectors
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Ten years ago, in 2015, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) made the first-ever detection of gravitational waves. These waves are ripples in space and time caused by huge cosmic events, like two black holes crashing into each other. This discovery opened a new way to study the universe.

**What happened** – Since then, LIGO’s twin observatories in the United States, along with similar detectors in Europe and Japan, have found hundreds of these gravitational waves. They have improved their sensitivity, allowing them to see farther into space and detect black hole collisions more often—about once every three days now. Scientists are now planning even bigger detectors, like the Cosmic Explorer, which will be ten times larger and could detect up to 100,000 black hole collisions each year.

**Impact** – These discoveries help us understand how black holes form and merge over billions of years. The new detectors will allow scientists to look much deeper into the universe’s history, even to times when stars and galaxies were forming rapidly. This means we will learn more about the universe’s past and the forces that shape it.

**What’s next step** – Scientists are working on upgrading LIGO to make it twice as sensitive and are searching for the best locations to build the Cosmic Explorer. They also plan to build a new underground observatory in Europe called the Einstein Telescope. These projects will take years and need funding, but they promise to turn gravitational wave detection into a routine way to study the cosmos.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After 10 years of groundbreaking discoveries, LIGO and its future upgrades aim to see thousands of black hole collisions each year, opening a new window into the universe’s history.
articles.personality_title_fr: LIGO fête ses 10 ans de découvertes sur les trous noirs avec des détecteurs encore meilleurs à venir
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a dix ans, en 2015, le Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) a réalisé la première détection de vagues gravitationnelles. Ces vagues sont des ondulations dans l’espace-temps causées par de grands événements cosmiques, comme la fusion de deux trous noirs. Cette découverte a ouvert une nouvelle façon d’étudier l’univers.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Depuis, les deux observatoires jumeaux de LIGO aux États-Unis, ainsi que des détecteurs similaires en Europe et au Japon, ont détecté des centaines de ces vagues gravitationnelles. Ils ont amélioré leur sensibilité, ce qui leur permet de voir plus loin dans l’espace et de détecter les collisions de trous noirs plus souvent – environ une tous les trois jours aujourd’hui. Les scientifiques prévoient maintenant des détecteurs encore plus grands, comme le Cosmic Explorer, qui sera dix fois plus grand et pourrait détecter jusqu’à 100 000 collisions de trous noirs par an.

**Impact** – Ces découvertes aident à comprendre comment les trous noirs se forment et fusionnent depuis des milliards d’années. Les nouveaux détecteurs permettront d’observer beaucoup plus loin dans l’histoire de l’univers, même à l’époque où les étoiles et les galaxies se formaient rapidement. Cela signifie que nous en apprendrons davantage sur le passé de l’univers et les forces qui le façonnent.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques travaillent à améliorer LIGO pour doubler sa sensibilité et cherchent les meilleurs endroits pour construire le Cosmic Explorer. Ils prévoient aussi de construire un nouvel observatoire souterrain en Europe appelé le télescope Einstein. Ces projets prendront des années et nécessitent des financements, mais ils promettent de rendre la détection des vagues gravitationnelles une méthode courante pour étudier le cosmos.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après 10 ans de découvertes majeures, LIGO et ses futures améliorations visent à détecter des milliers de collisions de trous noirs chaque année, ouvrant une nouvelle fenêtre sur l’histoire de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: LIGO celebra 10 años de descubrimientos de agujeros negros con detectores aún mejores en camino
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace diez años, en 2015, el Observatorio de Ondas Gravitacionales por Interferometría Láser (LIGO) detectó por primera vez ondas gravitacionales. Estas ondas son ondulaciones en el espacio y el tiempo causadas por grandes eventos cósmicos, como la fusión de dos agujeros negros. Este hallazgo abrió una nueva forma de estudiar el universo.

**Qué pasó** – Desde entonces, los dos observatorios gemelos de LIGO en Estados Unidos, junto con detectores similares en Europa y Japón, han detectado cientos de estas ondas gravitacionales. Han mejorado su sensibilidad, permitiéndoles ver más lejos en el espacio y detectar colisiones de agujeros negros con más frecuencia, aproximadamente una cada tres días. Ahora, los científicos planean detectores aún más grandes, como el Cosmic Explorer, que será diez veces más grande y podría detectar hasta 100,000 colisiones de agujeros negros al año.

**Impacto** – Estos descubrimientos nos ayudan a entender cómo se forman y fusionan los agujeros negros durante miles de millones de años. Los nuevos detectores permitirán a los científicos mirar mucho más atrás en la historia del universo, incluso a épocas en que las estrellas y galaxias se formaban rápidamente. Esto significa que aprenderemos más sobre el pasado del universo y las fuerzas que lo moldean.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos trabajan en mejorar LIGO para duplicar su sensibilidad y buscan los mejores lugares para construir el Cosmic Explorer. También planean construir un nuevo observatorio subterráneo en Europa llamado el Telescopio Einstein. Estos proyectos tomarán años y necesitarán financiación, pero prometen hacer de la detección de ondas gravitacionales una forma común de estudiar el cosmos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Tras 10 años de descubrimientos revolucionarios, LIGO y sus futuras mejoras buscan detectar miles de colisiones de agujeros negros cada año, abriendo una nueva ventana a la historia del universo.
